05/08/2017' Almost blizzard ! I went alone with high hope and hired skis with two day pass. Skis were not waxed well... Dropped my two-day lift pass in a black diamond run on the first day due to my skill and weather +/- skis. I went to the info staff and told her I dropped my paper pass. Staff replied first with "Would you like buy again?" Or I was told to use slope for free but to WALK up the slope with my skis! I asked what to do second day. She replied come back and sit until somebody returns your pass in the morning, which sometimes happens. She offered me if I wanted to buy again. I asked why they could issue the pass again even with my receipt, "Somebody out there is using your pass." Shameful service...
Giving paper pass with a plastic zip tie is not enough in this world. Old ski jackets used to have clear plastic pocket around left sleeve for the pass. But I haven't seen those ski jackets for years. They never warned me not to lose it. They only emphasized to hang the pass out on the jacket somewhere. I complained to the manager. No help. I was told it was the same in all Australian ski resorts. I showed him Falls Creek plastic card. I am sure he knew he was not telling the truth as one of the business operator. Second day's ski rental also gone! I did not go back second day as It was two hours driving from home.
They claim so-called small business like themselves cannot afford chipped plastic card like the rest of the world. Well, it all depends.
A few more issues and I will help them correct all for the public.

Plan to leave from 4pm.

name: Nicholas Houston
review_text:
Not very family friendly

I have a wife who has not skied and a 4 and 5 year old who had never seen real snow. We had never skied in Australia before. We wanted to book ski classes for my wife and children and buy lift tickets for all.

The group classes were booked out on the day we could go and the only available class was a private class at 9.30 am. The private classes do not come with lift tickets so we bought day passes.

We left Canberra in high hope at the crack of dawn and stopped in Cooma to hire gear. In the confusion I left my ski boots at the hire shop and I arrived in Selwyn without boots. No problem, I thought, I would hire boots at Selwyn.

On the road still at about 8.30 am we realised we were going to be late, and so we called Selwyn to see whether we could re-schedule the class. The answer was no, there were no other classes available, and we had lost our money. When I went to hire the new boots, the answer was no, they would not fit them to my skis for reasons of company "policy" and I had to hire a complete new set. When I asked whether we could hire a toboggan while waiting they said yes, but we would need special toboggan lift passes and could not use the skiing day passes we had.

When they subsequently discovered there were group classes available at 1 pm, the told us we had to pay again without any credit for the cancelled class and that we needed new lift passes. After an argument we gained a small credit for the lift passes we had.

The ski classes were run between the two buildings and neither child got out on to the snow proper because of the "mix of skills of the children" until I went to take the 5 year old from his class and have a proper ski.

In summary, the snow and the sun were magnificent but the Selwyn Snowfields resort does not own the snow and the sun. At every turn we found a policy that made the experience un-family friendly.

Sure, in the mess of organising skis, gloves, goggles, helmets, stocks, and fitting them to the excited body parts of a 4 and 5 year old, I, somehow left my boots in Cooma, and sure, after naively accepting the class start time of 9.30 am we were late. But we are a family, a fairly normal family wanting to do fairly normal things at a resort that advertises itself as family friendly.

Well, it is not that family friendly when you get into the detail but has a series of unnecessary policies that will view you as a walking wallet, nothing more. The snow is great, but prepare yourself mentally for everything else.
